*G.L. c. 212, \u00a74*.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to *G.L. c. 212, §4*, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

*G.L. c. 223, \u00a71*.proposition: Venue is proper in the Norfolk County Superior Court under *G.L. c. 223, §1*, because the events giving rise to this cause of action occurred in Quincy, Massachusetts, within Norfolk County.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant owed a duty to maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition for invitees such as Plaintiff, under Massachusetts common law, including *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing on landowners a general duty of reasonable care to all lawful entrants. While the provided excerpt is only a concurrence discussing classifications (invitee/licensee/trespasser), the decision as a whole stands for the proposition that occupiers must maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition for invitees (and other lawful visitors). Thus, citing Mounsey for a landowner’s common‑law duty of reasonable care to invitees is accurate, though it actually extends beyond invitees to all lawful entrants.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: [Summary of holding from Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973), not in the provided excerpt]: The court rejected the traditional common-law distinctions between invitees and licensees and held that "the proper test of a landowner’s liability is whether in the management of his property he has acted as a reasonable person in view of the probability of injury to others," thereby imposing a general duty of reasonable care toward all lawful visitors.

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Defendant also had a duty to take reasonable steps to inspect, clean, and warn of hazardous conditions, as recognized in *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973).
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors the usual premises-liability duty of reasonable care with respect to snow and ice, which includes making reasonable efforts to protect visitors from such hazards. This necessarily encompasses reasonable inspection, removal/cleaning, and, where appropriate, warning of dangerous snow and ice conditions, placing snow-and-ice hazards on the same footing as other premises dangers. Thus, Papadopoulos is proper authority for the asserted duty to take reasonable steps to inspect, clean, and warn of hazardous conditions arising from snow and ice.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.’ … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: Defendant also had a duty to take reasonable steps to inspect, clean, and warn of hazardous conditions, as recognized in *Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass. 368 (2010), and *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165 (1973).
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The court expressly states the duty of one who controls business premises to use due care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to warn of dangers that the possessor knows or ought to know about. That encompasses a duty to take reasonable steps to inspect and clean (so that hazards are discovered and removed) and to warn of such conditions. Although the case ultimately finds the evidence insufficient on the notice/time element, it clearly affirms the underlying duty described in the proposition.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: “The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know. … In the more usual case, however, the plaintiff attempts to establish the defendant’s negligence by showing that the foreign substance was present on the defendant’s premises for such a length of time that the defendant should have known about it.”

*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.proposition: Under *Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (1957), a business that creates a dangerous condition on its premises is liable if it fails to correct or warn against it within a reasonable time.
*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a state enforcement officer was a trespasser when he entered and briefly parked his vehicle on private property in the course of his official duties. It does not address premises liability, dangerous conditions created by a business, or any duty to correct or warn of such conditions. The holding is about lawful entry by public officers under statutory and common-law authority, so it does not support the claimed proposition about a business’s liability for dangerous conditions on its premises.
*Thurlow v. Crossman*, 336 Mass. 248 (19.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant in his capacity as enforcement officer was authorized, in the performance of his duties, to 'enter upon and pass through or over private property or lands whether or not covered by water.' ... It appears from the findings of the auditor that the defendant entered the premises to investigate suspected illegal activities relating to the taking of shellfish in the vicinity, a purpose within the scope of his duties as law enforcement officer... His original entry being lawful there was nothing in his subsequent conduct which served to make him a trespasser ab initio."

*Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo..raw_text: *Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo. 418, 494 P.2d 839 (1972)
*Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo..proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and losses were the foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, consistent with the standards of *Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo. 418, 494 P.2d 839 (1972) (adopted in Massachusetts cases addressing recurring slip hazards).
*Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo..case_name: Jasko v. F. W. Woolworth Co.
*Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that where a proprietor’s method of operation makes dangerous conditions continuous or easily foreseeable, injuries resulting from such hazards are a foreseeable consequence of the proprietor’s negligence, and conventional notice of the specific spill is not required. That is exactly the foreseeability concept later adopted in Massachusetts “recurring slip hazard” cases. The case links the store’s negligent method of sale to the predictable risk of customers slipping on food on the floor, thereby supporting the proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were a foreseeable result of defendant’s negligence.
*Jasko v. F.W. Woolworth Co.*, 177 Colo..relevant_excerpt: “The dangerous condition was created by the store’s method of sale. The steps taken to constantly clean the floor show that the store owner recognized the danger. The practice of extensive selling of slices of pizza on waxed paper to customers who consume it while standing creates the reasonable probability that food will drop to the floor. Food on a terrazzo floor will create a dangerous condition. In such a situation, notice to the proprietor of the specific item on the floor need not be shown… when the operating methods of a proprietor are such that dangerous conditions are continuous or easily foreseeable, the logical basis for the notice requirement dissolves.”

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a785*.proposition: Plaintiff acted with due care for her own safety and was not comparatively negligent within the meaning of *G.L. c. 231, §85*.

*Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945.case_name: Union Old Lowell National Bank v. Paine
*Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945.support_reasoning: Bateman v. Conway does not involve premises liability, landowner duties, or any duty to maintain safe physical property or warn of dangerous conditions. It concerns banking, agency, conversion, and issues of knowledge and negligence in financial transactions. Nothing in the opinion addresses a property owner’s duty regarding unsafe premises, so it does not support the cited proposition about premises liability under Massachusetts law.
*Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945.relevant_excerpt: “There was no finding indicating negligence of the bank, toward Paine Webber. ‘Where there is no legal obligation or duty to do an act, there can be no negligence in an omission to perform it.’ Combs v. Scott, 12 Allen, 493, 497. But, in any event, it is well settled that carelessness in the charge of property does not bar the owner (in this case the bank with the rights of a bailee) from proceeding against a converter of the property.”

*Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959).support_reasoning: The opinion holds that a property owner in control of a common area must exercise reasonable care to keep it in safe condition and can be liable where it knows of a dangerous condition (here, accumulated inflammable paper in a hallway) and fails to remedy it, leading to injury. The court explicitly applies the general rule that one in control of a building must exercise reasonable care to prevent injury to others and upholds liability based on the owner’s knowledge and failure to act, which fits the proposition about premises liability for known or reasonably knowable dangers.
*Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959).relevant_excerpt: “In Chalfen v. Kraft, 324 Mass. 1, 4-5, we ruled that the defendant, in possession and control of the cellar of a three apartment building… was subject to the rule ‘that a person in control of a building must exercise reasonable care to keep it in such condition that others will not be injured.’ … We think that the defendant’s control of a common hallway is not to be distinguished… We rule that it was a question for the jury whether the defendant should have contemplated that a fire or an intensified fire was a probable happening from the maintenance of the paper and cardboard in the hallway.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: Even though this is a dissent and focused on causation, it accepts (and explicitly states agreement with) the majority’s conclusion that the college was negligent in providing inadequate security and locking systems—i.e., that it owed and breached a duty to exercise reasonable care for student safety on its premises. That duty is consistent with the general Massachusetts proposition that a property owner must maintain reasonably safe premises and guard or warn against dangers it knows or should know of. The dissent disputes only proximate cause and foreseeability as to this plaintiff’s injury, not the underlying duty or standard of care.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt:
“I agree that the jury could have found that the system for locking the room door was inadequate due to the defendants’ negligence…”

“The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969).”

*Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App.raw_text: *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988)
*Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an employer’s liability for negligent hiring and retention of an employee who assaults a customer, not a property owner’s duty to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers. While it discusses a duty of reasonable care toward customers, it does so in the context of employment/selection of personnel, not premises conditions or warnings about physical dangers on the property. Thus it does not directly support the general premises-liability proposition stated.
*Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: The doctrine states that an employer whose employees are brought in contact with members of the public in the course of the employer’s business has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the selection and retention of his employees. … In this case, the plaintiff contended that Loft was negligent because the evidence demonstrated that Loft knew that Rida had a criminal record and did nothing to determine its nature or extent, or to assure itself that Rida’s past criminal activities were not such, in the circumstances, as to present a danger to customers.

*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.support_reasoning: The case narrows landowner liability rather than broadly affirming a duty to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers. The court holds that, as a matter of law, a residential landowner is not liable for a lawful visitor’s slip and fall on a natural accumulation of snow and ice where there is no separate defect or negligence, emphasizing that landowners are not insurers and that natural accumulations are not per se actionable defects. This is more restrictive than the general duty proposition for which it is cited.
*Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs correctly state that the duty owed by the defendants in this case was a duty of reasonable care in the circumstances. Mounsey, supra. The plaintiffs wrongly conclude, however, that the defendants breached this duty by failing to remove a natural accumulation of snow and ice on their property…. There is no evidence in this case which would allow a jury to find that the defendants failed to exercise reasonable care in the circumstances and created a defective condition on their property. In the absence of such evidence, there is no evidence of negligence by the McCloskeys.”

*Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass.raw_text: *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010)
*Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, including *Bateman v. Conway*, 318 Mass. 323 (1945); *Ross v. Broitman*, 338 Mass. 770 (1959); *Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47 (1983); *Foster v. The Loft, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 289 (1988); *Aylward v. McCloskey*, 412 Mass. 77 (1992); and *Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass. App. Ct. 354 (2010), a property owner is liable for failing to maintain safe premises and warn of dangers it knew or reasonably should have known existed.
*Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal procedure case about the adequacy of a guilty-plea colloquy, not premises liability or duties of property owners. It does not discuss a landowner’s duty to maintain safe premises or warn of known or reasonably knowable dangers. Citing this case for that Massachusetts premises-liability proposition is inaccurate and out of context.
*Reid v. Parkway Parking, Inc.*, 76 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
“Prior to exploring the seven complaints, a brief overview of the applicable law is in order. As the law is fairly well known in this area, we need not go into it in any great depth.
Discussion. A defendant’s guilty plea must be intelligently and voluntarily made… ‘A defendant’s plea is intelligent when made with understanding of the nature of the charges… and the consequences of his plea…; it is voluntary when free from coercion, duress, or improper inducements.’”

*G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a76B\u20136C*.proposition: C. Award prejudgment and post-judgment interest pursuant to *G.L. c. 231, §§6B–6C*;
